p: The tension between global and local descriptions (in time or space) is not unique to climate science, of course. It arises in any scientific context where statistical power is achieved by aggregation over an inhomogeneous population, and thus blurs information. There is a growing move in many fields towards analysis methods that aim to consider information in context rather than in aggregate, especially when that information is sparse (e.g. safety in healthcare [ 46]). Storyline approaches to climate risk can be seen as part of that movement.
